news.title: Men who kill women they know treated more leniently: study - NEWS 1130
news.summary: TORONTO (NEWS 1130) – A new Canadian study shows that men who kill their female partners are more likely to be criminally convicted than men accused of killing strangers.

news.title: Sentences lighter for men who kill female partners, Ontario study finds
news.summary: University of Guelph researcher calls more lenient treatment the “intimacy discount.” Share via Email Print Ryan Remiorz / The Canadian Press File Photo Femicide of a partner or family member is typically seen as a spontaneous “crime of passion” or…

news.title: Sentences are lighter for men who murder female partners: study
news.summary: The study found that men who kill wives, girlfriends, or other female members of their family are given shorter prison sentences than those who kill strangers, according to an article written by Colin Perkel for The Canadian Press, per Global News.

news.title: 'Intimacy discount:' Sentences lighter for men who kill female partners
news.summary: TORONTO - Men who kill their female partners are more likely to be criminally convicted than men accused of killing strangers — but they also tend to get lighter sentences, a Canadian study concludes.

news.title: 'Intimacy discount:' Sentences lighter for men who kill female partners
news.summary: TORONTO - Men who kill their female partners are more likely to be criminally convicted than men accused of killing strangers — but they also tend to get lighter sentences, a Canadian study concludes.

news.title: The ‘intimacy discount:’ Sentences lighter for men who kill female partners

facebook.title: Punishing femicide: Criminal justice responses to the killing of women over four decades
facebook.summary:
Myrna Dawson (University of Guelph, Canada) is the author of “Punishing femicide: Criminal justice responses to the killing of women over four decades” published in the November issue of Current Sociology, a Special Issue addressing  femicide.
